original_data.question: A 55-year-old male with a history of stage I colon cancer status-post left hemicolectomy presents to your office for follow-up. You intend to discuss the results from his recent surveillance colonoscopy, which showed no remaining cancer, no polyps, and a well-healed anastmosis. During your meeting, you note that the patient is exhibiting the defense mechanism of suppression. Which of the following statements from the patient is consistent with your impression?

options.A: "Last week I volunteered for the local Cancer Society. Helping other cancer patients just makes me feel better."
options.B: "Oh, doctor, I'm just so grateful to be seeing you. I just know you've cured my cancer. I probably don't even need to check anymore."
options.C: "I'm sorry I was late today. I also didn't get any of the labs you asked for."
options.D: "I really haven't thought about the colonoscopy until today. Worrying before getting the results wasn't going to help anything."

model_response:
Suppression is the conscious or semiconscious decision to not think about an anxiety-provoking event or situation. In this case, the patient is consciously avoiding thinking about the colonoscopy until he meets with you. His behavior is aimed at reducing anxiety in the short-term, but it may come at the expense of accurate information about his condition.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Surgical removal of the left part of the colon.
The result of a laboratory, radiologic, or other clinical test performed to determine the presence, absence, or degree of a condition.

A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Discrete abnormal tissue masses that protrude into the lumen of the DIGESTIVE TRACT or the RESPIRATORY TRACT. Polyps can be spheroidal, hemispheroidal, or irregular mound-shaped structures attached to the MUCOUS MEMBRANE of the lumen wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or by a broad base.
Surgical union or shunt between ducts, tubes or vessels. It may be end-to-end, end-to-side, side-to-end, or side-to-side.
The act or process or an instance of coming together.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

Unconscious process used by an individual or a group of individuals in order to cope with impulses, feelings or ideas which are not acceptable at their conscious level; various types include reaction formation, projection and self reversal.
A verbal and/or written message that asserts, affirms, or declares something.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Marked by a reasonable or logical relation of parts and holding together as a harmonious or credible whole.
